citations.narrative:
The facility is set up so that guests can buy food and feed the animals. During the inspection, there were multiple
members of the public, including young children, offering lettuce to an enclosure housing 7 giraffes. There was only one
attendant present in the giraffe public viewing area. The one attendant in this area was not able to simultaneously monitor
multiple encounters with different giraffes. Facility employees stated that typically two attendants are to be present at all
times during giraffe feedings. In the Dromedary camel public viewing area, there is a 3-foot chute extending from the
public barrier into the camel enclosure which patrons may use to feed the camels. There was no readily identifiable
attendant present in this area at the time of inspection. With limited or no attendants present to enforce and monitor the
interactions in these areas, there is an increased risk of harm to both the public and regulated animals. The facility must
ensure that a knowledgeable and readily identifiable attendant is present at all times during periods of public contact.
Correct by: 4/8/2023

In the enclosure housing 15 red kangaroos, there is an approximately 4-foot section and an approximately 3-foot section
of exposed PVC waterline pipe extending out of the dirt. In the enclosure housing 4 Springbok, there is an approximately
2-foot section of exposed PVC waterline pipe extending out of the dirt. The animals can chew or destroy the exposed
waterline pipes which may lead to injury, disruption of their water supply, or flooding of their enclosure. The facility must
ensure outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury
and to contain the animals. Prior to the end of inspection, there was sand placed over the sections of previously exposed
pipes in the kangaroo enclosure.
CORRECT BY: 3/15/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Tracie Guy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility is set up so that guests can buy food and feed the animals. During the inspection, there were multiple 
members of the public, including young children, offering lettuce to an enclosure housing 7 giraffes. There was only one 
attendant present in the giraffe public viewing area. The one attendant in this area was not able to simultaneously monitor 
multiple encounters with different giraffes. Facility employees stated that typically two attendants are to be present at all 
times during giraffe feedings. In the Dromedary camel public viewing area, there is a 3-foot chute extending from the 
public barrier into the camel enclosure which patrons may use to feed the camels. There was no readily identifiable 
attendant present in this area at the time of inspection. With limited or no attendants present to enforce and monitor the 
interactions in these areas, there is an increased risk of harm to both the public and regulated animals. The facility must 
ensure that a knowledgeable and readily identifiable attendant is present at all times during periods of public contact. 
Correct by: 4/8/2023 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In the enclosure housing 15 red kangaroos, there is an approximately 4-foot section and an approximately 3-foot section 
of exposed PVC waterline pipe extending out of the dirt. In the enclosure housing 4 Springbok, there is an approximately

2-foot section of exposed PVC waterline pipe extending out of the dirt. The animals can chew or destroy the exposed 
waterline pipes which may lead to injury, disruption of their water supply, or flooding of their enclosure. The facility must 
ensure outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury 
and to contain the animals. Prior to the end of inspection, there was sand placed over the sections of previously exposed 
pipes in the kangaroo enclosure. 
CORRECT BY: 3/15/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Tracie Guy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
